headline: Trump sues JPMorgan for $5 billion, alleges the bank closed his accounts for political reasons
summary: President Donald Trump sued banking giant JPMorgan Chase and its CEO Jamie Dimon for $5 billion on Thursday over allegations that JPMorgan stopped providing banking services to him and his businesses for political reasons after he left office in January 2021.  The lawsuit, filed in Miami-Dade County court in Florida, alleges that JPMorgan abruptly closed multiple accounts in February 2021 with just 60 days notice and no explanation.  “JPMC debanked (Trump and his businesses) because it believed that the political tide at the moment favored doing so,” the lawsuit alleges.

raw.headline: Trump sues JPMorgan for $5 billion, alleges the bank closed his accounts for political reasons
raw.summary: President Donald Trump sued banking giant JPMorgan Chase and its CEO Jamie Dimon for $5 billion on Thursday over allegations that JPMorgan stopped providing banking services to him and his businesses for political reasons after he left office in January 2021.  The lawsuit, filed in Miami-Dade County court in Florida, alleges that JPMorgan abruptly closed multiple accounts in February 2021 with just 60 days notice and no explanation.  “JPMC debanked (Trump and his businesses) because it believed that the political tide at the moment favored doing so,” the lawsuit alleges.

headline: Trump's call for a 10% credit card rate cap is 'inconceivable'
summary: Trump called on Congress to implement a 10% cap on credit card interest rates, but Wolfe Research head of US policy and politics Tobin Marcus says that the odds of the cap coming to fruition are "essentially zero," highlighting unintended consequences for consumers. Marcus tells Market Catalysts Host Julie Hyman that some of the other affordability-focused efforts that Trump has called for — like banning large institutional investors from buying single-family homes — and the Credit Card Competition Act are unlikely, but not "inconceivable" like the credit card rate cap. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

raw.headline: Trump's call for a 10% credit card rate cap is 'inconceivable'
raw.summary: Trump called on Congress to implement a 10% cap on credit card interest rates, but Wolfe Research head of US policy and politics Tobin Marcus says that the odds of the cap coming to fruition are "essentially zero," highlighting unintended consequences for consumers. Marcus tells Market Catalysts Host Julie Hyman that some of the other affordability-focused efforts that Trump has called for — like banning large institutional investors from buying single-family homes — and the Credit Card Competition Act are unlikely, but not "inconceivable" like the credit card rate cap. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Catalysts.

headline: Banking behemoth JP Morgan Nutmegs rivals with purchase of WealthOS
summary: JP Morgan Chase, the US-based banking giant, has swooped to buy a British pensions technology company as it tries to augment its retirement planning services to personal investing clients.  Sky News has learnt that JP Morgan has agreed to snap up WealthOS, which was founded in 2019.  Chaired by former Google executive John Herlihy, WealthOS is a wealth management software business.
